questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presents with bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. He is a known case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and is on treatment with an ABVD regimen for the past 4 months. What is the drug responsible for the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of flagellate dermatitis. It is a specific adverse effect of bleomycin.

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic. It acts by generating free radicals by binding with a reducing agent (iron) in the presence of oxygen. This metal-drug complex cleaves the DNA of the tumor cell.

It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of Hodgkin's lymphoma and testicular cancer.

Bleomycin has a bone marrow–sparing effect. The major adverse events include flagellate dermatitis and pulmonary toxicity, which may progress to pulmonary fibrosis.

Flagellate dermatitis starts as bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. These rashes heal with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. No treatment is necessary since the lesions usually disappear on the stoppage of the drug. These lesions respond to topical corticosteroids.

The image given below shows flagellate dermatitis.

Other agents causing flagellate dermatitis are docetaxel, bendamustine, and peplomycin.

Other options:

Option A: Adriamycin/doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug. It is used for the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis. 

Option C: Vinblastine is a vinca alkaloid. Adverse effects of vinblastine include leucopenia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia. Local reactions like cellulitis and phlebitis may occur on drug extravasation during the injection.

Option D: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma was started on a tyrosine kinase inhibitor that acts by inhibiting VEGF. He is now being evaluated for increasing protein excretion in his urine. Which of the following drugs was prescribed to the patient?

VEGF- Vascular endothelial growth factor
questions.solution:
Sunitinib is a small molecule, multi-targeted kinase antagonist/inhibitor and has been shown to have anti-tumor activity in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs). Proteinuria is a common adverse effect of the drug. 

Pharmacology of sunitinib:

  • Molecular targets of sunitinib are c-Kit, VEGFR-2, PDGFR-β and Flt-3.
  • Sunitinib targets mutations in the RET gene.
  • The mechanisms of sunitinib’s action are:Inhibition of activated c-Kit and PDGFR in GIST
  • Inhibition of VEGFR in advanced RCC

Adverse effects:

  • Its specific adverse effects include neutropenia, diarrhea and fatigue.
  • Generally, the other common side effects of agents having anti-VEGFR activity are hypertension and proteinuria.
  • Rarely, they cause bleeding and clotting disorders, and perforation of scarred gastrointestinal lesions.
  • Hand-foot syndrome has also been noted in the use of these agents, with erythema and desquamation of distal extremities.

Administration: In advanced RCC and in adjuvant therapy, sunitinib is given orally, at a dose of 50mg per day, once daily, with or without food, for 4 weeks out of 6 (nine 6-week cycles in adjuvant therapy).

Uses:

  • In metastatic GIST, the main chemotherapeutic agent used is imatinib, which is a selective inhibitor of the c-kit tyrosine kinase. Patients whose tumors have become refractory to imatinib benefit from agents like sunitinib, which also inhibits c-kit tyrosine kinase.
  • It is now undergoing studies for efficacy in hepatocellular carcinoma.

Update:

  • The drug was previously approved for use by various regulatory bodies in 2006, for conditions like GIST and advanced RCC.
  • In 2017, sunitinib maleate was approved by the FDA for use as adjuvant therapy for patients at risk for recurrence of RCC after a kidney has been removed (nephrectomy).
  • This was based on a multi-center, international, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial among 615 patients with high risk of recurrent RCC following nephrectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Ramucirumab is a human IgG1 monoclonal antibody that targets VEGFR2, preventing VEGFR ligand binding and thereby reducing ligand-induced activity in endothelial cells. It is used in combination with docetaxel to treat patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Adverse effects include hypertension and diarrhea.

Option C: Aflibercept is a recombinant fusion protein that functions as a VEGF trap by sequestering VEGF using the VEGFR1-binding domain. It is used in treating metastatic colorectal cancer

Option D: Pembrolizumab is a humanized monoclonal IgG4κ isotype antibody that prevents the interaction between programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) and its ligands. It is used in the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer, either before or after chemotherapy with platinum. It is also used in the treatment of melanoma, urothelial cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma and Hodgkin lymphoma. Serious adverse events include pneumonitis, colitis and hepatitis.

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for the treatment of glaucoma. He presents with complaints of extensive loss of orbital fat giving the appearance of a sunken eye. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this side effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of orbital fat atrophy and it is seen with topical PGF2α (prostaglandin) analogs like latanoprost.

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs are used as a first line in glaucoma. Latanoprost is the most commonly used anti-glaucoma medication. Other prostaglandin analogues are travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by altering the ciliary muscle tension and improving the outflow of the aqueous humor.

Adverse effects:

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema especially in aphakic patients. 
  • Orbital fat atrophy

Other options:

Option A: Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker used topically in glaucoma. Ocular adverse effects of beta-blockers include dryness and redness of the eye, stinging, corneal hypoesthesia, blurred vision, and allergic blepharoconjunctivitis. Systemic side effects like bradycardia and bronchospasm may be seen due to absorption through the nasolacrimal duct.

Option B: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent and adverse effects are corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia, and retinal detachment.

Option C: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and reduces intraocular pressure by reducing the aqueous humor formation. It is given orally and the systemic adverse effects are anorexia, paresthesia, hypokalemia, acidosis, and depression.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitations. ECG strip obtained is shown in the image below. His BP is 120/76 mm Hg. Vagal maneuvers were tried but failed. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This ECG strip is suggestive of the AV nodal reentry (AVNRT) variant of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. 

PSVT spans a variety of tachycardia that differ based on the pathway of impulse conduction. They include AV node reentry, AV reentry via an accessory pathway, and atrial tachycardia. AVNRT is the most commonly seen pattern of PSVT in healthy adults, especially in women. This form of PSVT is due to the re-entry of the electrical impulse from the AV node to the right atrium via either of the 2 pathways (superior fast pathway and inferior slow pathway).

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings-

  • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (green arrows) at 150 bpm - indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm. 
  • No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
  • The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) (black arrow) and pseudo-S wave (II, III, aVF) (blue arrows). 
 
 
Treatment - Since AVNRT depends on the functionality of the AV node, administering adenosine terminates most cases of tachycardia. This drug transiently blocks AV conduction by activating acetylcholine-sensitive K+ current in the atria, SAN, and AV nodes. These changes lead to a short action potential duration, hyperpolarization of the nodal tissues, and slowing of automaticity.
Intravenous verapamil or diltiazem can be used alternatively in patients who cannot tolerate adenosine.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman presented with features suggestive of thyrotoxicosis. Which of the following is not a treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Radioactive iodine therapy is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation. Therefore, it is not a treatment option in this patient.

Thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy:

The drug of choice for the treatment of thyrotoxicosis during the first trimester of pregnancy is propylthiouracil (PTU).

Methimazole and its prodrug (carbimazole) are usually avoided in the first trimester due to teratogenic risk. However, methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for PTU-associated liver failure. 

Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed during the mid-trimester.

Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and causes the destruction of the fetal thyroid. Therefore, it is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation.

Treatment of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

Trimester Treatment for thyrotoxicosis
First trimester
  • Propylthiouracil
Second trimester
  • Methimazole
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy
Third trimester
  • Methimazole

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)

  • Radioactive iodine

questions.text: A 64-year-old male is diagnosed with chronic congestive heart failure and is started on beta-blockers. His symptoms fail to improve, and he is started on a new drug. His BP is 132/80 mmHg, and his heart rate is 84 beats/minute. He now complains of visual disturbances characterized by a transiently enhanced brightness in particular areas of the visual field. What is the drug he was likely to have been started on?
questions.solution:
The patient was likely started on ivabradine. 

Ivabradine may be used in chronic heart failure patients who do not tolerate β blockers or have a heart rate of >75 beats/min even with β blocker administration. One of its common side effects includes the development of phosphenes. Phosphenes are transiently enhanced brightness in specific areas of the visual field.

Ivabradine selectively blocks the hyperpolarization-activated sodium channels (HCN) in the SA node to reduce the pacemaker current If (Na+ funny current channel) and decreases heart rate. It reduces heart rate without affecting myocardial contractility, ventricular repolarization, or intracardiac conduction. The antianginal effect is mainly by reducing heart rate and thereby decreasing the O2 demand of the myocardium.

Other side effects include bradycardia, QT prolongation, and atrial fibrillation.

The hyperpolarization cyclic nucleotide (HCN) channels are also present on the retina. These channels on continuous blockade by ivabradine are hyperpolarized and lead to increased brightness in restricted areas of the visual field. These phenomena are known as phosphenes. 

Normally, the signal transduction pathway in the retina involves the opening of HCN channels. This leads to the influx of calcium to activate cGMP and causes recovery from light to dark. In cases where HCN channels are blocked, this pathway is affected and recovery from light to dark takes time resulting in increased brightness. The image attached below shows a normal transduction pathway.

Ivabradine is contraindicated for use in combination with diltiazem or verapamil.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came to the emergency department with severe pain in both legs, after she underwent an induced abortion using ergotamine. On examination, her legs were cold and pale, and peripheral arterial pulses were not felt. Which of the following drugs can be used as an antidote in treating the condition?
questions.solution:
Nitroprusside can be used as an antidote to reverse the ergot-induced vasospasm.

Nitroprusside is a non-selective vasodilator. It acts by releasing NO, which activates the guanylyl cyclase - cyclic GMP – protein kinase G pathway, leading to vasodilation. This mechanism mimics the production of NO by vascular endothelial cells.

Therapeutic uses:

  • It is primarily used in the treatment of hypertensive emergencies.
  • To lower blood pressure during aortic dissection. It is important to administer beta blocker with nitroprusside in aortic dissection to reduce heart rate, because if nitroprusside is given alone, it causes increased myocardial contractility, which in turn increases the rate of increase in aortic pressure and may further aggravate the dissection.
  • To improve cardiac output in patients with congestive heart failure, especially with hypertension and pulmonary edema, who are refractory to other treatments.
  • To decrease myocardial oxygen demand after myocardial infarction.
  • To induce controlled hypotension during anesthesia, and reduce bleeding during surgical procedures.
  • To reverse the vasospastic action of the ergot alkaloids, such as ergotamine and ergonovine.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain was prescribed a drug that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog. Mechanism of action is a combination of effects as mentioned below-

  • Weak agonist action on the mu-opioid receptor
  • Inhibition of serotonin reuptake transporter (moderate action) and norepinephrine reuptake transporter (weak action). 

It is used to induce analgesia for moderate pain and can be used as an adjunct to opioid therapy in chronic pain conditions. 

Other options: They do not affect serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

Option A: Hydromorphone is a phenanthrene drug with strong mu-opioid agonist action with a variable affinity for delta and kappa receptors. It is similar to morphine.  

Option C: Buprenorphine is also a phenanthrene derivative that has mixed opioid agonist-antagonist activity. It is a partial mu-agonist and has antagonist activity at delta and kappa receptors. While it can serve as an analgesic, it antagonizes the action of strong mu-agonists such as morphine. It is used to treat moderate pain and reduced cravings in patients recovering from alcoholism.

Option D: Hydrocodone is a phenanthrene drug with mild-moderate mu-opioid agonist action. It is less efficacious than morphine.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient came to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain in the right side of lips, gums, and cheek. It occurs during both day and night and lasts for 2-3 min and has been present for 3 weeks. What is the primary agent in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms are suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. If carbamazepine is not effective then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used. 

Trigeminal neuralgia is more common in women over 50 years of age. It is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory. Bilateral or early onset is associated with multiple sclerosis. Unilateral trigeminal nerve compresion can be due to superior cerebellar artey.

The pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief. This occurs spontaneously or is triggered by touch, cold wind, or eating. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). There are no objective signs of sensory loss.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to your clinic with crampy abdominal pain, constipation, and bloating on and off for the past 10 years. Pain occurs frequently after meals and is relieved after defecation without any bleeding while defecating. On examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate management for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's condition is irritable bowel syndrome with constipation and the drug used for this condition is lubiprostone.

The ROME IV criteria is used to diagnose irritable bowel syndrome, which requires at least 3 days a month in the last 3 months associated with 2 or more of the following:

  • improvement in abdominal pain or discomfort with defecation
  • onset associated with a change in frequency of stool
  • and/or an onset accompanied by a change in form or appearance of stool

It is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in female patients >18 years). It acts by stimulating the Cl-channels opening in the intestine and increasing liquid secretion in the gut. This decreases the transit time.

Other options:

Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist which is indicated only for women with severe diarrhea-predominant IBS who have chronic IBS symptoms ( lasting 6 months or longer) and have not responded adequately to conventional therapy. Serious GI adverse reactions like ischemic colitis, serious complications of constipation have been associated with its usage.

Rifaximin is indicated for irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea (IBS-D) in adult men and women.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: Your friend is planning a trip to the mountains but is concerned because of her history of severe nausea and vomiting while traveling anywhere. Which of the following drugs would be the least effective in managing her condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ondansetron is the least effective in managing motion sickness.

Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT and does not suppress vomiting caused by motion sickness. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text: A patient was given metoclopramide for severe vomiting.  After which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. The observed adverse effects are due to?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the patient has developed extrapyramidal adverse effects like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. This is likely due to the antagonist action on dopamine receptors by metoclopramide.

Metoclopramide is a prokinetic and antiemetic. It has the following pharmacological actions:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT4) receptor agonist 
  • Serotonin (5HT3) antagonist
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscle. This results in increased lower esophageal sphincter tone and stimulates gastric antral contractions.

Metoclopramide acts on both the gastrointestinal system and central nervous system. It is used as an upper antiemetic for many types of vomiting, especially migraine, drug-induced, and chemotherapy-induced. It is also used as a prokinetic in gastroparesis to increase gastric emptying.

Adverse effects of metoclopramide are mainly extrapyramidal effects, and these include acute dystonia, Parkinson-like symptoms (tremors, bradykinesia, rigidity), tardive dyskinesia, galactorrhea due to hyperprolactinemia, and methemoglobinemia in neonates.

Extrapyramidal symptoms can be treated by discontinuation of metoclopramide and administration of anticholinergics or antihistaminics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman with a family history of breast cancer presents with persistent lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured, and the T-score is -2.6. She is prescribed raloxifene. Which of the following effects of this drug should the patient be informed about?
questions.solution:
This post-menopausal patient with a family history of breast cancer, with osteoporosis (low back pain, a T-score of -2.6), has been recommended to take raloxifene. Raloxifene causes a 3-fold increase in deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with the following actions-

Agonist actions:

  • Bone: Increases bone mineral density and reduces the risk of vertebral fractures
  • Lipids: Reduces total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein. However, it does not increase HDL cholesterol.
  • Increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. 

Antagonist action:

  • Breast: Incidence of breast carcinoma is reduced (option D). Raloxifene has an antiproliferative effect on ER-positive breast tumors and significantly reduces the risk of ER-positive but not ER-negative breast cancer.
  • Uterus: does not stimulate endometrial proliferation (option B)

Note: Raloxifene does not help with vasomotor symptoms, and some people might experience hot flashes (option A).

SERM Effect on breast  Effect on endometrium Effect on bone
Tamoxifen Inhibits proliferation Stimulates proliferation Antiresorptive
Raloxifene Inhibits proliferation Inhibits proliferation Antiresorptive

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Family history of osteoporosis

Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting. He was immediately given an intramuscular injection of a drug in 1:1000 dilution. The drug acts on which of the following receptor to improve the patient's breathing difficulty?
questions.solution:
The patient's complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting are suggestive of anaphylactic shock. The drug of choice for anaphylaxis is intramuscular adrenaline (0.5ml in 1:1000 dilution). Activation of beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation. Hence, adrenaline action on the beta 2 receptors improves the breathing difficulty in this patient. Apart from this, beta 2 receptors also inhibit the secretion from mast cells.

Other options:

Receptor Action Use in anaphylaxis treatment 
Alpha 1 and Alpha 2 Vasoconstriction Increase in BP
Beta 1 Cardiac stimulation Increase in BP
Beta 2 Bronchodilation Reverse bronchoconstriction 


The net effect of adrenaline on BP: Adrenaline rapidly increases blood pressure by reversing vasodilation and improving cardiac output. This is critical for preventing shock and ensuring adequate perfusion to vital organs during anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to your OPD with severe constipation. After ruling out pathological causes, which of the following is the safest to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Lactulose is safe to use in pregnant women with constipation.

Constipation in pregnancy:

Constipation is a common occurrence in pregnancy because of dietary alterations, anatomic impingement of a large uterus on the rectosigmoid, fluid shifts, decreased exercise levels, and reduced mobility. Pregnancy and pregnancy-related constipation increases the risk for developing haemorrhoids.

Treatment options include

  • Dietary changes - increased water intake, increased fibre in diet
  • Gentle exercises
  • Laxatives - Lactulose, an osmotic purgative, and Ispaghula, a bulk forming agent, are safe to use in pregnancy. 

Senna, bisacodyl, docusates and saline laxatives’ safety is unknown and hence it is better to avoid them.

Note:

Laxatives are drugs that promote bowel evacuation.

Classification of Laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming agents 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran
    • Psyllium, Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
    • PG analogue: Lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose
    • Lactitol

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions requires treatment with pulsatile doses of GnRH agonists?
questions.solution:
The pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in the treatment of male infertility.

Pulsatile administration of GnRH agonist increases FSH and LH secretion and is used to treat male and female infertility.

A non-pulsatile or a continuous dose of GnRH agonist results in suppression and decreased concentrations of gonadotropins (LH and FSH). Hence, it cannot be used in the treatment of male infertility. 

Non-pulsatile (Continuous) administration of GnRH analogs used in: 

  • Endometriosis
  • Uterine fibroids
  • Central precocious puberty
  • Ca prostate
  • Ca ovary and breast
  • Controlled ovary stimulation

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability.  An X-ray of his skull is shown below. Laboratory investigations show decreased hemoglobin, hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR. He should be started on which of the following combination therapy?
questions.solution:
This patient's history and clinical findings are suggestive of multiple myeloma. Lenalidomide +Bortezomib+Dexamethasone is the treatment of choice in multiple myeloma.

This patient's anemia, hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR are consistent with the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The skull demonstrates the typical “punched out” lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma. 

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common presenting symptom in multiple myeloma. The next most common clinical problem in patients with myeloma is susceptibility to bacterial infections. The most common infections are pneumonia and pyelonephritis, and the most frequent pathogens are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella pneumoniae in the lungs and Escherichia coli and other gram-negative organisms in the urinary tract.

Chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation prolongs overall survival in multiple myeloma patients.

The combination of lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone achieves close to a 100% response rate making it one of the preferred induction regimens in transplant-eligible patients.

NOTE: The U.S. FDA has approved ABECMA, the first cell-based gene therapy to treat adult patients with multiple myeloma who have not responded to, or whose disease has returned after, at least four prior lines (different types) of therapy.

questions.text:
A patient with pulmonary hypertension comes for a vasoreactivity test. What drugs can be used if the test is negative?
  1. Bosentan
  2. Amlodipine
  3. Sildenafil
  4. Latanoprost
  5. Riociguat
questions.solution:
The drugs used for pulmonary hypertension if vasoreactivity test is negative are 1, 3, and 5.

Bosentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist, sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE5) inhibitor, and riociguat is a soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulator used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension

Vasoreactivity testing involves the administration of inhaled nitric oxide, IV epoprostenol, or adenosine. The test is considered positive if the mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAH) decreases.

  • Positive vasoreactivity test: Calcium channel blockers (CCB) are indicated. Nifedipine, diltiazem or amlodipine are used.
  • Negative vasoreactivity test: Drugs other than CCBs are used.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that is a PGF2α derivative. It reduces intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is not used in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: At around 11.30 PM, a 45-year-old man is wheeled into the casualty with anginal pain for which the consultant advises nitrates. On administration of nitrates, his BP suddenly drops and the patient goes into sudden hypotension. On probing into his medical history, his wife mentions that he has been taking a drug for erectile dysfunction. What is the likely mechanism of the action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Erectile dysfunction is treated by phosphodiesterase 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, and tadalafil. PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates should not be prescribed together due to an increased risk of hypotension.

The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection. PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP and are, therefore, used in the management of erectile dysfunction.

Drug interactions of PDE-5 and nitrates- PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP by preventing its degradation and therefore cause vasodilation. Since nitrates also act by increasing cyclic GMP mechanism, they can therefore potentiate the effects of PDE-5 inhibitors. Hence, men treated with PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates are at risk for severe hypotension and syncope.

Adverse effects of PDE-5 inhibitors-

  • The most common side effects reported include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, nasopharyngitis, and dyspepsia. Rare but serious reports of prolonged erections lasting more than 4 hours and priapism (painful erections lasting more than 4 hours) have been reported with PDE5 inhibitors. 
  • Sildenafil and vardenafil also cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision.
